Literature Review: ATP-binding cassette (ABC) transporters are a large family of membrane proteins that play critical roles in cellular physiology by transporting a wide variety of substrates across cellular membranes. In humans, the ABC transporter family comprises 48 genes, which are organized into seven distinct subfamilies (A to G). Among these, 44 genes encode for membrane transporters that are involved in diverse physiological processes, including drug resistance, lipid homeostasis, and the pathogenesis of several diseases due to transporter dysfunction. The importance of ABC transporters in human health and disease has spurred extensive research into their structure and mechanism, leading to significant advances in our understanding of these complex proteins. Recent breakthroughs in structural biology, particularly the advent of cryo-electron microscopy (cryo-EM), have revolutionized the field by enabling the determination of high-resolution structures of human ABC transporters that were previously inaccessible. These structural insights have provided unprecedented details into the molecular architecture, regulation, and substrate interactions of ABC transporters, shedding light on their functional mechanisms. One of the key findings from structural studies is the conserved architecture of ABC transporters, which typically consists of two nucleotide-binding domains (NBDs) that bind and hydrolyze ATP, and two transmembrane domains (TMDs) that form the substrate translocation pathway. The ATP-driven conformational changes in the NBDs are coupled to the TMDs, facilitating the transport of substrates across the membrane. Structural studies have also revealed the diversity in the substrate-binding sites and transport mechanisms among different ABC transporter families, reflecting their wide range of physiological roles. For instance, the ABCB1 (P-glycoprotein) transporter, which is involved in multidrug resistance, has been shown to possess a large, flexible binding pocket that accommodates a variety of chemotherapeutic drugs. In contrast, the ABCA1 transporter, which is crucial for cholesterol efflux and high-density lipoprotein (HDL) biogenesis, has a more specialized binding site for lipids. The structural elucidation of these transporters has not only enhanced our understanding of their physiological functions but also provided a basis for the development of therapeutic strategies targeting ABC transporters. For example, the structural insights into ABCB1 have informed the design of inhibitors to overcome multidrug resistance in cancer therapy. Similarly, the structural characterization of ABCA1 has opened new avenues for the treatment of cardiovascular diseases by modulating cholesterol transport. Despite these advances, challenges remain in the structural and functional characterization of human ABC transporters. Many ABC transporters are difficult to purify and stabilize for structural studies, and their dynamic nature poses additional challenges for capturing their functional states. Moreover, the physiological relevance of structural data obtained from model systems, such as bacterial homologs or engineered constructs, needs to be carefully evaluated in the context of human ABC transporters. Computational modeling and structure prediction methods have emerged as valuable tools to complement experimental approaches, providing insights into the conformational dynamics and substrate interactions of ABC transporters. However, the accuracy and reliability of these methods depend on the quality of the input data and the underlying algorithms. Future research directions in the field of human ABC transporters include the integration of structural, biochemical, and biophysical approaches to unravel the complex mechanisms of these transporters. The development of novel techniques for the stabilization and structural analysis of ABC transporters, as well as the exploration of their roles in disease pathways, will be crucial for advancing our understanding and therapeutic targeting of these essential proteins. In conclusion, the structural and mechanistic studies of human ABC transporters have made significant strides in recent years, driven by technological advancements in cryo-EM and computational modeling. These studies have provided valuable insights into the molecular basis of ABC transporter function and their implications in human health and disease. Continued efforts in this field hold promise for the development of novel therapeutic strategies to modulate the activity of ABC transporters in various pathological conditions.
